Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we assess the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our findings suggest that without any interventions, over 14 million individuals would have died by May 17, 2020. However, starting interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths worldwide. We also observed that restrictions on mass gatherings and school closures led to significant reductions in infection rates, with average decreases of 29.6% and 17.3%, respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home orders, resulted in an average reduction of 74.4% in infection rates among countries that implemented it. Additionally, we showcase how our DELPHI model can forecast future COVID-19 incidence under different government policies, as demonstrated by Janssen Pharmaceuticals in selecting trial locations for their vaccine candidate Ad26.Cov2.S. For more information, refer to the e-companion at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Li et al. (2023) conducted a study on forecasting COVID-19 under government interventions and found that the most implemented policy category across the world is the stringent stay-at-home order. The implementation length and effect of each policy category were analyzed, with more stringent policies being associated with larger decreases in the residual infection rate compared to less restrictive policies. The study highlights the importance of timely implementation of effective government interventions to combat the spread of COVID-19.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. (2020) discussed the importance of R0 in measuring the spread of infections in a population. R0 represents the average number of new infections generated by one infected patient in the early stages of an epidemic. To control the spread of infection, the effective reproduction rate Rt should be less than 1. Policies such as stay-at-home orders have shown to effectively mitigate the epidemic, albeit at a high economic and social cost. Timing is crucial in implementing these policies to minimize the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling alternative initial responses, such as starting mitigation efforts earlier, can significantly impact the outcome. For instance, starting interventions just one week earlier could have prevented around 280,000 deaths globally by May 17. On the other hand, leaving the epidemic unmitigated would have resulted in over 14.8 million deaths by the same date.

pre_context: Modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Hunan, Japan was the focus of a recent research article published in Quantitative Biology 2020. Conducted by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various institutions in Japan, the study aimed to provide insight into the epidemic progression and mitigation strategies. The coronavirus disease has seen significant spread in Japan and globally within a short period, prompting urgent research efforts into understanding and managing the situation. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, Japan (excluding Hunan), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate in Hunan as 0.0643, which is lower than Hunan excluding Hunan (0.1914) and Japan excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, the rate increases to 0.3229 after new diagnosis guidelines were implemented on February 12. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hunan on February 12 is estimated to be 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict COVID-19 will end in Hunan and Hunan by late March, in Japan excluding Hunan by mid-March, and in tier-one cities before early March. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with the majority in Hunan. Our model suggests maintaining quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hunan. Additionally, the model can be beneficial for predicting epidemic trends in other countries facing a high risk of outbreak. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading worldwide, with unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting confirmed cases. Our SUQC model helps to understand and predict the dynamics of COVID-19.

contents: location: chongqing, hunan, hong kong; time: february 1, 2020
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this research article, Zhao and Chen model the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Hong Kong. The study examines the rapid spread of the disease in Hong Kong and in more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Chongqing, Hunan (excluding Chongqing), Hong Kong (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Hong Kong. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Chongqing at 0.0643, which is lower compared to Hunan excluding Chongqing (0.1914) and Hong Kong excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, the rate jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when new diagnosis guidelines incorporating clinical evidence were adopted. On February 12, 2020, the estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing was 3,509, dropping to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Chongqing and Hunan by late March, in Hong Kong excluding Hunan by mid-March, and before early March 2020 in the four tier-one cities. In total, there are estimated to be 80,511 infected individuals in Hong Kong, with 49,510 in Chongqing, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Chongqing), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of Hong Kong (excluding Hunan). These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hunan until late March. Our model can be valuable in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in Hong Kong and internationally. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model effectively captures the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from Hong Kong to predict trends.

RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in India and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. This disease presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention efforts. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Mumbai, Maharashtra (excluding Mumbai), India (excluding Maharashtra) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Mumbai estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Maharashtra excluding Mumbai (0.1914), and that of India excluding Maharashtra (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. Estimates show that the number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 in Mumbai and Maharashtra will likely end by late March, mid March for the rest of India, and before early March for tier-one cities. In total, there are an estimated 80,511 infected individuals in India, with a majority from Mumbai and Maharashtra. It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Delhi, Kolkata, Bengaluru, and Chennai until early March, and in Maharashtra until late March. This model can also be useful for predicting the epidemic trend in other countries at high risk of outbreak. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and other countries, with unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation and time delays between real dynamics and confirmed cases. Our SUQC model helps to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and provide guidance for countries at risk of outbreak.

Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Context: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and over 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

Approach: We have developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to study the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly considers the effects of control measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other epidemic models.

Findings: Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, Jingzhou (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Jingzhou), and four major cities in China. The analysis showed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures effectively curbed the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jingzhou excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jingzhou (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Jingzhou is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Jingzhou, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Jingzhou (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Jingzhou). Please be aware that the estimates presented are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our recommendations suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Jingzhou. This model can also be utilized to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between actual transmission dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, utilizing daily data from China to predict the epidemic's trajectory and provide guidance for other at-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries over the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread. To better understand these dynamics, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model, which takes into account the intervention effects of control measures. Applying this model to the daily data of confirmed infections, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions in Japan. Our findings show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R greater than 1, indicating rapid spread. However, after January 30, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R less than 1, suggesting that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Tokyo estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Kanagawa excluding Tokyo (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Kanagawa (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Tokyo on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Tokyo and Kanagawa is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Kanagawa, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Tokyo, 17,679 from Kanagawa (excluding Tokyo), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Kanagawa).The estimates provided in this study are derived from a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Osaka, Nagoya, Fukuoka, and Yokohama, and until late March in Kanagawa. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer a numerical guide for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and numerous other countries. It possesses distinctive characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Japanese data to predict epidemic trends. This model can also provide valuable guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

These findings underscore the necessity and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in managing the epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had significant effects on global public health and economy, leading to repercussions across various sectors. This research was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various institutions in Brazil, emphasizing the importance of data science and computational intelligence in analyzing epidemic models like SEIR through agent-based simulations.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for guiding politicians and health authorities in planning their responses to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The outbreak, caused by SARS-CoV-2, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The WHO declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. Brazil confirmed its first case on February 25th, 2020. As of June 26th, 2020, the country had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. The pandemic has also impacted various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, society, environment, and climate, as well as global supply chains and production. Social distancing measures have been deemed as the most effective way to combat the spread of the disease, with different levels of success seen in countries around the world. Given the complexity of societies, accurately predicting the future actions and consequences of the pandemic remains challenging.

pre_context: While the initial simulation lacked accuracy in economic dynamics due to the absence of social constructs and periodic routines, their inclusion significantly improved the performance of economic response variables. These social constructs and periodic routines are pre-programmed but can be adjusted by users, offering flexibility. The parameter set allows for representing anything from a single community to an entire country. The experimental methodology involved seven scenarios reflecting various social distancing measures, implemented using an ABS model in Python 3.6. The source code is available at https://bit.ly/covid_abs_experiments and https://bit.ly/COVID19_ABSsystem. Each scenario simulated the impact of a specific social distancing policy on response variables, with 35 executions and 1,440 iterations each.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. author: chunwei
pre_context: Considering uncertainties in the data is important in modeling, as data at each time point can follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance given by the assumed probability distribution, which may vary depending on the mean. The lack of data is a significant issue for modellers, as understanding the relationship between confirmed cases and model predictions is crucial. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been tested and confirmed to have COVID-19. The infected compartment in transmission models represents all infected individuals, including those with and without symptoms, contacts with hospitals, confirmed lab tests, and those who may be misdiagnosed. Confirmed cases are just a fraction of the total infected population predicted by the model - a metaphor of an iceberg illustrates this well, with the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface representing the cases data and the part hidden under the water symbolizing the undetected infected population, known as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2. In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC.
Why is this a problem for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by fitting it to confirmed case data, it is crucial to adjust the total number of infectious individuals I(t) using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed cases. Different values of r can result in varying estimates of the transmission rate b, which in turn affects the basic reproduction number R0 and the timing of the epidemic peak. The wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19 leads to a wide range of estimated transmission rates b and, consequently, a wide range of model predictions. This nonidentifiability phenomenon, where multiple sets of parameters can fit the data equally well but lead to different predictions, poses a challenge in model calibration. Traditional methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to address nonidentifiability due to their basic optimization algorithms. How nonidentifiability is managed during model calibration significantly impacts the reliability of model predictions.

Unlike SARS, where individuals typically become infectious two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. Evidence for COVID-19 suggests that individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms, although the exact length of the latent period remains unknown. The SEIR model is considered more biologically realistic compared to the SIR model, but it also introduces two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Transfer diagrams for both models can be found in Fig. 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters in Tables 1 and 2. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are minimal during the model prediction period (4 months). The death term in the R compartment does not impact model fitting, as we calibrate the models using newly confirmed case data. The differential equations for each model are provided below.

Model calibration from the data For data reliability, the data used for both models (2) and (3) is the newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China city from the official reports from January 22 to February 4, 2020 (National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, 2020). It is common to use a Poisson or negative binomial probability model for observed count data. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. Since the newly confirmed cases are approaching large values quickly, the distribution of the count data will be approximately normal and the probability model for the observed count data in our study was assumed to a normal distribution with mean given by rI and variance given by 1= t. We used uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models. Posterior distributions for estimated parameters were obtained using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. Best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained for both models. The corrected Akaike Information Criteria for the SIR and SEIR models were calculated to be 174 and 186, respectively. The difference suggests that the SEIR model may result in a loss of information compared to the SIR model, so further investigation will focus on the SIR model. We also found a linkage between the transmission rate and diagnosis rate in the SIR model.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
PLOS COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY presents Covasim, an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies but generally increases with severity. Our model reflects this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases (Table 1). Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2). 

Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a scenario where each person has around 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 results in a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7, varying based on factors like population size and age structure. The β value currently used in Covasim (0.016) was calibrated to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were chosen to have a relative weighting of 10:2:2:1 for consistency with time-use surveys and studies of known contact types. In the absence of interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the transmission rate (β). Individual infectiousness can vary based on factors such as viral load, which peaks around symptom onset and then decreases over time. This model includes two stages of viral load, with the high stage lasting for 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. These values are consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. Daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability for each individual.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is included (e.g., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. By default, transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen based on time-use surveys and previous studies, with a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, around 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The value of β can be modified by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, we allow for differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness, using individual viral load to model variations in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington D.C. and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 shows viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by location; estimated proportions for Seattle are provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling needs or context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
